result.rationale: This species is known from the type locality in the Trinité massif, French Guiana. It has a restricted distribution with an an area of occupancy (AOO) best estimated at 4 km<sup>2</sup>. There is one location based on the threat of mining according to  regional experts. This is leading to a continuing decline in habitat. Therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered.
result.geographicrange: This species is only known from the type locality in the Trinité massif, French Guiana (Covain et al. 2012).
result.population: Only one subpopulation is known for this species (P.-Y. Le Bail pers. comm. 2021).
result.habitat:
This species is found in river rafts and permanent streams, including waterfalls (P.-Y. Le Bail pers. comm. 2021).

All Harttiella species live in small forest streams and are subservient to areas of torrents at the head of watersheds, where predatory fish seem to be absent. Their environment is characterized by running water and an essentially rocky substrate, supplemented by plant debris from the forest cover. Harttiella species have adapted to this biotope by evolving into dwarfism. They have low fertility and low dispersal capacities, which make them particularly vulnerable to any disturbance to their environment (UICN France et al. 2017).
result.threats: The species is threatened by mining activities (UICN France et al. 2017).
result.conservationmeasures: The species is nationally considered as Critically Endangered in French Guiana (UICN France et al. 2017).
result.usetrade: This species is sought after by aquarists due to its rarity (P.-Y. Le Bail pers. comm. 2021).
